text: hi everyone updating late on oh here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this poll og record
the goat this is the second full-length
album from Chicago native and Columbia
Records recording artist poll og I have
been on the fence with this record now
for a little bit and maybe to a degree I
still AM but honestly the more I listen
to this the more excited I actually feel
for Paulo Gees future in music now take
a look at the title take a look at the
cover we're not surprised this is a
hip-hop project right it can be
categorized as pop rap or trap rap or
gangster rap it's all reflected in the
lyrics pretty clearly the fame the watch
is the designer clothes the money the
violence the drug-dealing
themes that have all been explored
pretty widely and deeply in this wing of
hip hop for a while now but there is
something about this that doesn't strike
me as the average trap project in fact
poll og barely even strikes me as a
rapper oddly enough he sounds more like
a singer-songwriter to me obviously poll
og is far from the only artist singing
and trap music right now it's pretty
much a requirement at this point but the
vocal melodies on his songs are
surprisingly dynamic the narratives of
his tracks to fluid there's also a lot
of focus on personal tragedy and mental
health in his writing to what polo ji
writes and says and sings on this LP is
certainly thoughtful but I wouldn't
necessarily go as far as to say that
it's conscious hip-hop this record is
not a dissection of street life or a
macro commentary on the web of systemic
oppression that creates these conditions
polo ji is also no stranger to gun talk
on this record though when he's doing it
sometimes it seems like it's it's a
result of him accepting his fate
basically seeing futility in fighting
the nightmare he is stuck inside of I
stood 10 toes I couldn't folder panic
them streets will turn a good kid into a
cold little savage no point in Church
because the preacher can't keep them
pulls from clapping
seemed like evil by soul attractin hope
for forgiveness for my sins while I load
the ratchet so polo ji can obviously do
chilling and harrowing on this record
when he wants to but a good deal of the
time his songwriting comes off more
heart wrenching to one degree or another
such as the track no matter what where
you have pristine piano leads sound
tracking bars like standing on that
corner like a Russian we can't get
enough war zone I'm on my way to school
got my blicker tucked prayed to the Lord
for better days feel like he's skipping
us you got to either die or see the
system ain't no slipping up polo then
takes listeners down an even more
traumatic path on the song I know where
he reflects on his own mental
instability surviving abuse having trust
issues as well and the depth with which
he dives into these topics the detail he
gives listeners it's pulling the veil
further back than I think most writers
are willing to regardless of genre
moments like this on this record of
which there are some are just really
emotionally devastating even when polo
is just doing his best to set the tone
for the record on don't believe the hype
the way his lyrics and the
instrumentation rolls out it just sounds
like a movie to add to the tragedy of
this record there is a posthumous juice
world feature on here which is pretty
good the song it comes off of is a
banger and a half
clearly this track comes from a time
when days were maybe a bit brighter but
just a few tracks later on the song 21
we have poll og addressing juice world's
death in a few bars so there are
multiple tracks on this thing that
ranked as some of my favorite hip hop
songs of the year but damn there are
aspects of this album that falls so
fantastically short most of these flaws
coming from the production mixing and
mastering Department oh Jesus how could
a major label project come out with the
beats sounding so thin and so generic
for the majority of the record I would
say the only smart thing poll og does
with all of the
is very basic very skeletal somewhat
weepy piano and guitar laced beats is
that he hits listeners with them so
consistently it kind of becomes a style
and an aesthetic if you pulled out most
of these beats just out of context threw
them out of any other record they would
be just forgettable as hell the trap
percussion on many songs here even on
the intro track is lacking in punch
clarity separation the little baby
feature on the back end of be something
is mixed so quietly it's almost like the
nav feature on astro world all over
again but for some reason people aren't
laughing this time around I don't know
why his voice sounds so damn quiet why
is even on the track Pole oh geez vocals
and lyricism often makes up for how
lackluster the production is but not
always in the case of the song 33 it
really like sucks the winds out of the
sails and just leaves the song feeling
very gray meanwhile the track goes
stupid with Stunna for Vegas and NLE
chiapas insanely hard-hitting production
from Mike will made it it's crazy to
think that a record has a song like this
that hits so hard so much volume so
bright so much flavor to it and then
there are cuts here that are so insanely
quiet and I don't mean that in the sense
that oh they're mellow or oh they're
low-key like clearly they're being
mastered at different volumes and I
don't know why I mean I know if this
were a louis tomlinson album it wouldn't
be going out like this but you let the
Polo G record go out like this come on
Columbia Jesus the production also leads
to a lack of style and diversity toward
the end of the record so you do get one
or two redundant tracks polo G even
seems to be painting himself into a
corner vocally as well especially on the
song relentless as well as Chinatown
where his vocal lines come off quite
tedious not sure how crazy I am as well
about the faint pho Far East musical
samples that are laced throughout the
beat sure it's a change of pace but they
are boring as hell so while the second
act of this record generally is not as
strong as the first it does give us two
killer closing tracks bj the chicago kid
sounds fantastic on the closer wishing
for a hero which is essentially a flip
bore features an interpolation of
Tupac's changes this song also sees
polar G transitioning into the most
socially aware politically charged
content he writes on the entire record
some really fiery rapping on this one
you can tell he is digging down vocally
on this one and when he writes and spits
lines like they killed Martin for
dreamin and now I can't sleep that is
again just one of many devastating
moments on the record look overall I
liked this project quite a bit even with
there being some massive sonic flaws on
it which again I think is a tribute to
just how good a lot of Polo G's singing
and songwriting on this thing is and I
just walk away from this seeing a lot of
potential for what polo G could be doing
down the road from here like making a
mistake if he could somehow keep his
storytelling fresh and maybe link it
together into a greater narrative or
something over production that is just
way better and quality more diverse and
sound and obviously like not mixed or
mastered like crap he could make a
mind-blowing project one of the best
projects of this decade and I don't know
I'm just gonna cross my fingers here I'm
gonna cross my fingers here and just
hope and pray to Jesus that it happens
feeling a light too decent 7 on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe please don't cry hit the bell
is well over here next to my head is
